59:00 You can always decompose nth degree linear diffrential equation into n*n matrix of simultanous first order equations which is always solvable by matrix exponentation. But not always computable by the matrix exponentation, so you might still want to solve the original differential equation to get to the values. This then come to preference how you do it but all those will contain in some place complex numbers. Your methods might hide them but they were there whgen t hose methods were concieved. So to learn how to solve linear cdifferential equations of order 2 & higher it is customary always use complex numbers and then show how it is sometimes possible to do what you want to do without them if you want. But in the end you might not want to beacause you realise that the moste elegant solutions are the ones with complex numbers and all other methods are more cumbersome. Except the matrix exponentation. It's there to give a end in your paper where you want to show that there is a valid way to express explicitely your solution.

In the sense of "transformation", all complex numbers (real, complex or purely imaginary) have the exact same level of "existence".

the way i answer the z^2 = i is by defining z = (a + bi)
(a + bi)^2= i
(a^2 - b^2) + 2(ab)i = i

so i have to find a and b so that
(a^2 - b^2) = 0 or a^2 = b^2 ...(1)
and
2(ab)i = i or ab = 1/2... (2)

from a^2 = b^2 we can see that a is equal to either b or -b, and because ab is positive it means that a=b. putting that into the second equation give us a=b=√(1/2) which give us z = √(1/2) + √(1/2)i or you can write it as z = √2/2 + (√2/2)i

The question about the non-real cube roots of 1 is always going to have a special place in my heart. I remember one time I was being difficult and pestering my parents, so my father gave me that question. He didn't tell me how many there were; he just told me to find them. I had only just learned about complex numbers, so I didn't know about the analog between multiplication and rotation, but that problem let me figure it out on my own. Also, I think we were hiking, so I didn't have any pencil or paper, and I had to visualize it in my head (but that's easier for me than algebra anyway). That was a really fun few hours.

I didn't even realize until he told me years later that he was trying to get me to stop bothering him, but apparently giving me difficult math problems was a strategy he used to use. It certainly worked, and I got a few really fond memories out it.

My professor summarised the complex system as “just an extension of real numbers, don’t worry why or how”. Today I learnt some beautiful new concepts that make so, so much sense. Why are they not expanded upon usually?

I've loved complex numbers. I get to use them as an electrical engineer who models the power grid (AC analysis). It is why I choose EE over civil or mechanical, although system engineering is pretty cool.

I enjoy exploring some of the more philosophical questions of understanding in math, the ones that don't have "right" answers and that professors and professional seldom consider.

How are X-Y coordinate systems different than complex numbers? When and how we conceptualize and learn about them is a large part of the answer, IMO. We aren't introduced to 2-D grids (geospatial math concepts of X-Y coordinates) until after we study arithmetic (counting, addition, subtraction, multiplication, powers, and exponents; basics of numbers); about the time we start learning about algebra (variable manipulation and properties). Complex numbers are only introduced later when we start investigating a negative number to a power of a non integer. Function theory has typically been introduced by that point and a belief in determinism is setting in. I'd point out that in a way, complex numbers bridge the gap between X-Y coordinate systems and trigonometry (although trig is normally when the intersection starts. Complex numbers just takes it a step further). My point, I liked how you segwayed to What should the complex numbers be called (rotational numbers -sneaky numbers) and the discussion around the physics i, j, k or geospatial x,y,z (3-D). Complex numbers focus on rotation in a deep way a lot of trig does not, although polar rectangular transformations are a thing that is glanced over.

If you consider a number to be real, Which is real? Which exists?
2 2^.5 (-1)^.5 infinity
Numbers aren't real in the sense that objects are real. Count are more attributes of how we conceptualize and quantify objects. Integers are a more obvious manifestation of objects that people have an easy time agreeing on how the system is defined. Irrational numbers with non finite values, that can only be approached with limit, feels less real. Same with imaginary numbers. Infinity is such a high level concept that I hesitate to even consider it a number. A numerical concept, sure, I can get behind that. His concession that a application makes numbers real is interesting. "As real as words are." That is a good point. Happiness feel conceptually as vague as infinity. Just saying.

The multi dimensionality of complex numbers (and X-Y coordinate systems) and the information that extra dimensionality is what makes the system so interesting. It feels orthogonal, not linearly independent. Or as you said, a number can have multiple dimensions. From the power grid perspective, it allows concepts to move from the time domain to the frequency domain. The multi dimensionality, in a sense, allows us to freeze time. It allows for a transformation of concept (time to frequency domains in this case). Reactive power doesn't exist as an instantaneous quantity. MVAr is a unit or measure of parasitic effects of energy storage devices. It has impacts on how you evaluate the health, performance, and analysis, but it is not real in the same way that real power is real.

Renee Decarte coined these as derogatory to make fun of the "imaginary" component. I'd never heard that.

Even vector calculus is used in complex numbers, at least the vector part. Interesting how X-Y coordinates seldom reference vectors. I suppose we take baby steps.

I would assert that infinities, transcendentals, irrationals, and all numbers significantly exceeding the estimated number of atoms in the visible universe (or the reciprocal thereof) are imaginary, in that they can’t represent any quantity in physical reality. They can only represent theoretical quantities.

Let’s take pi for example. Mathematically speaking it has no end. However, pi to 50 digits is more than sufficient to calculate the circumference of the visible universe to significantly less than the diameter of a Hydrogen nucleus. Therefore, no problem in physical reality needs digits of pi beyond 50 decimal places.

However, that doesn’t make those numbers any less useful in performing math(s). Math itself isn’t “real”, it’s an abstraction created by man to aid in life. A few thousand years ago, there was no zero, nor negative numbers, then they were invented for accounting purposes, and they are extremely useful. And those very large and very small numbers need to “exist” to handle intermediate results and abstract theoretical models that are used in the proof of “closure” of the systems of mathematics.

Finding the 3 cube roots of 1 is actually very easy algebraically. x^3 = 1 ---> x^3 - 1 = 0. But the left side factors nicely into (x - 1) (x^2 + x + 1). Setting x - 1 = 0 gives you the real root, 1. You get the two complex roots by setting the second factor to 0 :  x^2 + x + 1 = 0. That's a quadratic, which you can solve very quickly with the quadratic formula. A really mind-blowing example of the use of i in the real world comes up with Pythagoras theorem. It is sometimes stated as s^2=x^2+y^2+z^2. But that no longer holds true in relativistic speeds. In an inertial system, it is possible to include time as a fourth dimension and get a correct solution. But only if scaled by ic (where i is square root of -1 and c is the  speed of light). So it turns out you get s^2=x^2+y^2+z^2+(ict)^2=x^2+y^2-c^2t^2. This s^2 will be the same for all observers, regardless of speed.

I would like to offer a very important counterexample from physics. The Schrodinger equation (describing the time-evolution of the wave function of a particle) relies intrinsically on complex numbers in a way most physics doesn't. Most people that deal with complex numbers in an introductory physics setting encounter them as a handy tool for dealing with electromagnetic signals and systems.

A very common place you might see this is when engineers express current and voltage using complex numbers (particularly phasors) as a way of handling differences in phase of the signal representing voltage and the signal representing current. If you have a circuit with a voltage source (AC), and a resistor and a capacitor in series, both of those can be represented using impedances. In that simple case, the impedance of the resistor is a pure real number (R) and the impedance of the capacitor is a pure imaginary number ( -j/Cs). So the total circuit has a voltage-current relationship like V=ZI, where Z=R-j/Cs and V and I are expressed as phasors.

In this case, the use of phasors and complex numbers is a useful fiction, as everything CAN be expressed using differential equations without resorting to any imaginary components. In the dynamics of a wavefunction, however, we have i*hbar*dpsi/dt = H*psi. In the one dimensional case, assuming low speeds, H*psi is usually written as V(x,t)*psi - hbar/2m* d^2 psi/dx^2.

If you look at that right-hand side, hbar is a real number expressing quantization of energy, m is the (real number) mass of the particle, and V is the (also real number) potential energy. If the wavefunction (psi) is real, then so is its second derivative, and hbar, and 2m and V... so the whole of H*psi is real. If you now look at the left, we have the (real) hbar, and the real number time derivative of psi... but we have that multiplied by i. So an imaginary number (i*hbar*dpsi/dt) is somehow supposed to equal a real number (H*psi). Fundamentally, the dynamics of wavefunctions demand that they are complex-valued, as otherwise the only solution to their equations of evolution would be if they were for all time and space equal to 0. (0i = 0+0i = 0)

For most of the places complex numbers are used, yes they are simply a useful way of organizing quantites related in some sense by rotation or to represent factors of irreducible quadratics. In the physics of the atomic scales, however, complex numbers are indeed necessary to correctly formulate how particles behave.

- 1 does not really exist. "Negative 1" is really subtracting 1 from another number. No negative numbers exist independently, just as temperature cannot be "negative 1 degree kelvin", but it can be negative 1 kelvin compared to this morning. @1:01:22 you can find the root pretty easily by just solving the equation

Defining Z = a + bi
(a + bi)(a + bi) = i
a^2 + abi + bia - b^2 = i
a^2 + 2abi - b^2 = i
The real and imaginary parts can be considered separately to obtain a set of equations.


Re(a^2 +2abi - b^2) = Re(i)
a^2 - b^2 = 0
a = +/- b

Im(a^2 + 2abi - b^2) = Im(i)
2ab = 1
ab = (1/2)


Combining those solutions:
a = b = sqrt(1/2) = sqrt(2)/2 (or a = b = -sqrt(2)/2)

And you have the answer. Doesn't generalize well into higher dimensions, though.

Why not "plane numbers" for complex numbers ? An maybe "high numbers" instead of imaginary : they indicate the height (y-axis) in the plane and you pronounce "high" almost like "i".

One reason for using matrices instead of complex numbers, (even for 2D transformation in computer graphcis) is that chaining transformation is just a multiplication. It means that translating then rotating is expressed in just one matrix, and you can add any transformations later on by multiplying matrices. With complex numbers, you can't translate using multiplication. It means that if you want to translate your points, then rotate them, then translate the result, you will need to store 3 distinct complex numbers AND remember whether you need to add or multiply them instead of just 1 matrix that you just have to multiply no matter how many transformations you added to it.i

But it depends on what you need to do. If the only way you want to rotate your object is "around itself" then scaling/translation, you can use one complex numbers and rotation one other. This could (maybe ?) be more efficient, but as computers are optimized for operations like cumulative multiplication (like in matrix computation) and parallel computation, it is not even worth bothering with complex numbers.

Quaternions on the other hand are extremely useful to prevent gimbal lock which can happen when using matrices in 3D.

Regarding memorizing the sum angle formulas:


cos(a+b) is some form of ±f(a)g(b) ± h(a)j(b), where f,g,h,j are some choice of sin and cos. We can worry about the sign of the terms later.


First observation — cos(a+b) is symmetrical in a and b (reversing the roles of a and b doesn't change the answer), and so f(a)g(b) is symmetrical iff h(a)j(b) is. WLOG, this indicates that if f = g, then h = j; if f ≠ g, then h ≠ j. So, we are able to reduce the problem to two general cases: cos(a+b) = ±f(a)f(b) ± g(a)g(b) and cos(a+b) = ±f(a)g(b) ± g(a)f(b), where f,g ∈ {sin, cos}. (The same goes for sin(a+b).)


Second observation — cos(a+b) is an even function, so the expression equalling that must also be an even function. This discounts cos(a+b) = ±sin(a)cos(b) ± cos(a)sin(b) because cos(-(a+b)) = ±sin(-a)cos(-b) ± cos(-a)sin(-b) = -[±sin(a)cos(b) ± cos(a)sin(b)] = -cos(a+b), which is impossible, so cos(a+b) = ±f(a)f(b) ± g(a)g(b).


Third observation — cos(a+0) = cos(a), so cos(a+0) = ±f(a)f(0) ± g(a)g(0), and we can only assure identity if f = cos and g = sin. Furthermore, the first ± can't be -, so it must be +.


Forth observation — when a = b = π/4, cos(a+b) = cos(π/2) = 0, so cos(a)cos(a) = ±sin(a)sin(a), but sin(π/4) = cos(π/4) = √[1/2] > 0, so cos(π/4)cos(π/4) = sin(π/4)sin(π/4), so cos(a+b) = cos(a)cos(b) - sin(a)sin(b).


For sin(a+b), the first observation reduces us to one of ±f(a)f(b) ± g(a)g(b) or ±f(a)g(b) ± g(a)f(b), as in cos(a+b). We use the observation that sin(a+b) is odd to reject the possibility of ±f(a)f(b) ± g(a)g(b) because both sin(a)sin(b) and cos(a)cos(b) are even under the transformation a,b ↦ -a,-b, and no sum or difference of such functions is odd under a+b ↦ -(a+b), and also immediately gives us that f≠g, so sin(a+b) = ±sin(a)cos(b) ± sin(b)cos(a). Symmetry again gives us sin(a+b) = ±(sin(a)cos(b)+sin(b)cos(a)), and sin(a+0) = sin(a) gives us sin(a+b) = sin(a)cos(b) + sin(b)cos(a).

Pi = (2.ln(I))/I

So,pi = ln(-1)/I
=Ln(-1).(1/i)
=Ln(-1^(1/I))

I like to play around with 3d graphics and I've come across quaternions  multiple times. They are actually used, math libraries designed for graphics or games always include quaternions as far as I know. That said quaternions are very often transformed into rotation matrices before heavy computations that involve rotations (like transforming millions of vertices in a modern 3d videogame) bacause GPUs are designed to be fast at matrix math. They can also be multiplied togheter before applying them to all of the vectors so you can do rotation, scale, non uniform scales, translations, projections(that involve the use of homogeneous coordinates in some cases) ecc. with a single matrix multiplication. Of course many of those things could be done with quaternions alone but I think that having hardware that can do matrix multiplication really fast is just more usefull than having hardware that can compute quaternions really fast.

I mean rotating using matrices or complex numbers is computationally identical, it's only useful to do so if your programming language already has complex numbers defined (no need for an external library)

Regarding why programmers use matrices to represent rotations instead of complex numbers, it's because it's computationally simpler: in N dimensions you can represent translation as a sum of N-dimensional vectors and rotations and streteches as a product. However, if you use N+1-dimensional vectors and matrices, everything becomes a product. And you can "accumulate" your very complex graphics transformation that includes translation, rotation, changing reference points and so on into a single matrix (the product of all the individual matrices for each operation). And thus whatever change you perform on your graphic becomes a matter of multiplying your control points by just that one matrix. Complex numbers are just a layer of 'rules' on top of 2D points. That's all. - Teachers just like to confuse students with weird notation, and pretending it's something else.
Simple definition:
x:R -> [x, 0]:C //all real numbers map to complex vectors
[-1, 0] == [0, 1]*[0, 1] //extra rule for new identity
x + yi == [x, y] //mostly just weird notation, but helps with algebraic way to multiply these 'vectors' -- really, you can think of yi as scaling a vector: y[0,1]
- Then it just turned out this weird thing can act as a generalized number ... and that's it. (in other words: it works to scale the vectors with other vectors with this property)
- In even other words: scaling and multiplication work the same way
-- for simple derived rules:
[a, b] * [c, d] == [ac - bd, ad + bc] //I'm not sure, but just defining multiplication like that might be a better axiom than the ([-1, 0] == [0, 1]*[0, 1])

In our calculus course we introduced complex numbers differently. We got a homework in which we were asked to find a field extension of R which is also a 2-dimensional algebra over R (or to prove that no such extension exists). I still know sitting in front of this and thinking "how the f am I supposed to 'multiply' points in the plane." Of course, no intuitive operation defined on 2D coordinates actually defined a multiplication, so I moved away from coordinates and tried thinking of operations I can do to dots in the plane which satisfy the field axioms. Rotations around the origin seemed to play nicely with addition. Thinking about xx^(-1)=1 gave me the idea of multiplying lengths, and boom, I had a field extension... just no clue how to formalize "rotations", because up until this point we had no complex numbers, cos, sin or exp. So I did what every student with a solution and no way to formalize it does: Let alpha(p) be the counterclockwise "angle" between p and the x-axis, let r(p) be the distance of p to the origin, and define p*q to be the point uniquely determined by alpha(p*q)=alpha(p)+alpha(q) mod 2pi and r(p*q)=r(p)*r(q).

It's called complex 'numbers', but it's not a set of number, it's a number system. Number systems consists of data structures and operations. Unfortunately, number systems are often designed (at least by syntax and notation) in a way that kind of hides this fact and make it look as if it was only a set of numbers.

The actual data structure of complex numbers is very simple. It's 2-dimensional numbers. This is the same data structure as in another number system, 2d vectors. It only differs in the available operations.
The main operations are:
* component-wise addition (same as in 2d-vectors, so not much to talk about)
* RotateAndScale
RotateAndScale takes two arguments: The original point and another point which defines the angle of rotation and the scaling factor. The result of the operation is a new 2d point. How an angle of rotation and scaling factor can be defined by a 2d point is explained in the video. One interesting fact from this is that the rotation is given by the angle between (1, 0), (0, 0) and one of the points. Note that this gives one dimension a special meaning because angles are measured towards the horizontal axis and not the vertical one.

That's basically all you need to know, but now comes the confusing part: Syntax and naming.

Lets start with naming:

The numbers are called "complex numbers", and that's a fitting name because it's a complex of two numbers. Here "complex" has the same meaning as "composition" and is not meant as the opposite of simple. But every other 2d point is also a complex of two numbers. We already have at least two names for this: 2d point and 2d vector. There's nothing different to justify a new name. Naming not the numbers but the number system "Complex number system" would be better, but that has it's own problems I'm not going into the details here.

The components of the 2d point are called "real part" and "imaginary part". Tbh, this is just confusing and does not add much benefit. The only important point is to know which part is on the axis towards which rotations are measured (see above) so giving the dimensions different names kind of has a purpose. Otherwise, calling it x and y component would work just as fine. Or use the names of the domain in which it is applied, e.g. if you want to use it to describe the relation between the potential and the kinetic energy of a pendulum, one component is called the potential energy and the other is the kinetic energy. Both have the same unit in this example, but can be different in other examples. One problem I have seen over and over again when complex numbers are applied to real world problems is that the "imaginary" axis is thought of to be abstract anyway, so no unit is given and no name is given to say which part of the real world it describes. Even worse: It hides the fact that you have to start in a 2d domain to even be able to apply it. People don't know when it's ok to use complex numbers as a result and when the right answer would be that no solution exists just because they don't know if they operate on one- or two-dimensional data.

Syntax/notation:
Complex numbers are written like this: "a + bi". It's just the point (a, b), but less obvious that it's a point. And looks even more confusing when your axis have different units like this: 2m + 3Joule * i.

Syntax of RotateAndScale:
RotateAndScale is just a function, so the obvious way would be to write it as
newPoint = RotateAndScale(startPoint, pointDefiningTheRotationAndScaling)
or
c_new = RotateAndScale(c1, c2)
or
(x_new, y_new) = RotateAndScale((x1, y1), (x2, y2))
But it's actually written with the same operator symbol as the multiplication:
c_new = c1 * c2
or
a_new + b_new * i = (a1 + b1 * i) (a2 + b2 * i)
Be careful. It has the same symbol, and it shares some properties (it's distributive etc.) but It's still a different operation! The only way to know which actual operation is meant is to look at the arguments. If one of the arguments is a complex number, it's not just a multiplication. If both arguments are not complex numbers, well you have to guess. Unfortunately, you can't tell if it's actually a non-complex number because the notation for a 2d point (a, 0) is the same as for a 1d point a. That's because the "+0i" part in "a +0i" is defined as optional. It doesn't always make a difference in the result, because RotateAndScale with (a, 0) doesn't rotate and is just scaling (or multiplying) by a. a1*a2 and (a1+0i) * (a2 +0i) do not have the same result (because one is one-dimensional and the other is two-dimensional) but both results have the same notation, so it doesn't matter. Both are just written as whatever a1*a2 is.

So if the results are the same, why bother with which operation it actually is at all? Because there are cases where the results are not the same. When you want to know which number y multiplied by itself is a given value x, you write it as y=sqrt(x). Well, imagine the actually symbol for square root which I just can't input here in the text. For complex numbers, the same notation is taken for a similar but different question: Which 2d point c1 rotated and scaled by c1 is c2? Notated as c1=sqrt(c2). The difference is that only one of those has a solution for negative numbers. If for example you have a real life problem where you have to take the square root of -2, there are two possible answers. First: You have a one-dimensional problem and it doesn't have a solution. Or second: Your actual problem is not taking the square root of -2, but the "square root" of (-2, 0) or -2+0i. And the solution is a 2d point that describes a rotation by a right angle and some scaling.
That means that:
* There is an actual second dimension involved in your problem
* That dimension can be named and has a unit
* Your input was a 2d point all along but you didn't notice
* Your mutiplications actually were RotateAndScale -operations all along
* Rotation could be applied in a way that makes sense because the values of the dimensions are somehow linked. Like the potential and kinetic energy in the example above which are linked because they can be transformed into each other. The rotation transforms values of one dimension into values of the other dimension. There must be a real life reason why they can be transformed, e.g. a physical law.
* The dimensions are scaled in a way that the rotation makes sense. In the above example, measuring kinetic energy in joule and potential energy in calories wouldn't give you a nice one to one transformation and therefore the rotation wouldn't make much sense (without more math to fix it)

All these points are giving you insight into your actual problem. If you encounter a square root of a negative number and "just do the math" because you know complex numbers, you miss all of that.

I think the name "imaginary" is amazing and beautiful. People who don't like it are people who dismiss the power of "imagination." All numbers exist in some sort of platonic realm, in some sense only concepts in our minds, only "imaginary," and yet in their ability to explain and define the patterns of universe, are somehow also "real." In this sense, all numbers are both "imaginary" and "real." And so, these names of "real" and "imaginary" numbers can be considered illogical misnomers, and yet, by naming the two axes of the 2-dimensional number-line the familiar "real," and uncanny "imaginary," we are reminded of this beautiful platonic duality. I absolutely love the idea of imaginary and complex numbers because of this deeply poetic name. Thinking about the "realness" of the "imaginary" numbers allows me to ponder the "complex" relationship between our real external world, and our imagined internal ones.
